section.title: Troubleshooting Centralized Logging
section.para: This section contains the following scenarios:

section.title: Reviewing Log Files
section.para: You can troubleshoot service-specific issues by reviewing the logs. After logging into Kibana, follow these steps to load the logs for viewing:

listitem.para: Navigate to the Settings menu to configure an index pattern to search for.
Click the green Create button to create and load the index.
Navigate to the Discover menu to load the index and make it available to search.

note.para: If you want to search specific &elasticsearch; indices, you can run the following command from the control plane to get a full list of available indices:

section.para: Once the logs load you can change the timeframe from the dropdown in the upper-righthand corner of the Kibana window. You have the following options to choose from:

listitem.para: Quick - a variety of time frame choices will be available here
Relative - allows you to select a start time relative to the current time to show this range
Absolute - allows you to select a date range to query

section.para: When searching there are common fields you will want to use, such as:

listitem.para: type - this will include the service name, such as keystone or ceilometer
host - you can specify a specific host to search for in the logs
file - you can specify a specific log file to search

section.title: Monitoring Centralized Logging
section.para: To help keep ahead of potential logging issues and resolve issues before they affect logging, you may want to monitor the Centralized Logging Alarms.

listitem.para: Log in to &opscon;.
From the menu button in the upper left corner, navigate to the Alarm Definitions page.
Find the alarm definitions that are applied to the various hosts. See the for the Centralized Logging Alarm Definitions.
Navigate to the Alarms page
Find the alarm definitions applied to the various hosts. These should match the alarm definitions in the .
See if the alarm is green (good) or is in a bad state. If any are in a bad state, see the possible actions to perform in the .

section.para: You can use this filtering technique in the "Alarms" page to look for the following:

listitem.para: To look for processes that may be down, filter for "Process" then make sure the process are up:
&elasticsearch;
Logstash
Beaver
Apache (Kafka)
Kibana
Monasca
To look for sufficient disk space, filter for "Disk"
To look for sufficient RAM memory, filter for "Memory"

section.title: Situations In Which Logs Might Not Be Collected
section.para: Centralized logging might not collect log data under the following circumstances:

listitem.para: If the Beaver service is not running on one or more of the nodes (controller or compute), logs from these nodes will not be collected.

section.title: Error When Creating a Kibana Visualization
section.para: When creating a visualization in Kibana you may get an error similiar to this:
section.screen: "logstash-*" index pattern does not contain any of the following field types: number

listitem.para: Log in to Kibana.
Navigate to the Settings page.
In the left panel, select the logstash-* index.
Click the Refresh button. You may see a mapping conflict warning after refreshing the index.
Re-create the visualization.

section.title: After Deploying Logging-API, Logs Are Not Centrally Stored
section.para: If you are using the Logging-API and logs are not being centrally stored, use the following checklist to troubleshoot Logging-API.

entry.para: Check any alarms Monasca has triggered.
Check to see if the Logging-API (monasca-log-api) process alarm has triggered.
Run an Ansible playbook to get status of the &lcm;:
Troubleshoot all specific tasks that have failed on the &lcm;.

row.entry: Ensure that the Logging-API daemon is up.

entry.para: Run an Ansible playbook to try and bring the Logging-API daemon up:
If you get errors trying to bring up the daemon, resolve them.
Verify the Logging-API configuration settings are correct in the configuration file:

section.title: Re-enabling Slow Logging
section.para: &mariadb; slow logging was enabled by default in earlier versions. Slow logging logs slow &mariadb; queries to /var/log/mysql/mysql-slow.log on FND-MDB hosts.
As it is possible for temporary tokens to be logged to the slow log, we have disabled slow log in this version for security reasons.
To re-enable slow logging follow the following procedure:

listitem.para: Login to the &lcm; and set a mariadb service configurable to enable slow logging.
Check slow_query_log is currently disabled with a value of 0:
Enable slow logging in the server configurable template file and confirm the new value:
Commit the changes:
listitem.screen: git add -A git commit -m "Enable Slow Logging"
